clusters.title: Pakistan and Afghanistan trade deadly strikes
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistan declares state of ‘open war’ after bombing major Afghan cities
bullet_summary: Pakistan's defence minister has said the ​country ‌is in an "open ​war" with neighbouring Afghanistan, after both nations launched strikes overnight
Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly airstrikes

items.title: Pakistan and Afghanistan trade deadly strikes
items.standfirst: Pakistan declared “open war” on Afghanistan after the two countries traded attacks in a sharp escalation following months of tensions. NBC News' Raf Sanchez reports on what led to fighting between the neighboring nations.
items.content: Pakistan declared “open war” on Afghanistan after the two countries traded attacks in a sharp escalation following months of tensions. NBC News' Raf Sanchez reports on what led to fighting between the neighboring nations.

items.title: Pakistan declares "open war" with Afghanistan as airstrikes rock Kabul
items.standfirst: Pakistan bombed major Afghan cities and declared "open war" after Afghanistan's Taliban rulers claimed an unprecedented aerial attack on Islamabad.
items.content: Pakistan bombed major Afghan cities and declared "open war" after Afghanistan's Taliban rulers claimed an unprecedented aerial attack on Islamabad.

items.title: Pakistan says it's in an "open war" with Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Pakistan's military launched airstrikes toward Afghanistan as tensions remain high in the region. CBS News' Ramy Inocencio reports.
items.content: Pakistan's military launched airstrikes toward Afghanistan as tensions remain high in the region. CBS News' Ramy Inocencio reports.

items.title: Pakistan declares 'open war' against Afghanistan
items.standfirst: #Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Kabul and three other Afghan provinces overnight between Thursday and Friday, authorities in #Afghanistan said, as the former's defence minister said that the countries were now in "open war".
items.content: #Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Kabul and three other Afghan provinces overnight between Thursday and Friday, authorities in #Afghanistan said, as the former's defence minister said that the countries were now in "open war".

items.title: Civilians flee fighting after Pakistan bombs Afghan cities
items.standfirst: After an Afghan cross-border attack on Thursday night, Pakistan carried out overnight strikes on Kabul and declared what it called an “open war” with Afghanistan, sending civilians in border areas fleeing to safety.
items.content: After an Afghan cross-border attack on Thursday night, Pakistan carried out overnight strikes on Kabul and declared what it called an “open war” with Afghanistan, sending civilians in border areas fleeing to safety.

items.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict: 'Localised clashes still going on'
items.standfirst: Localised clashes are still continuing along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border while Taliban officials say Pakistani aircraft continue to fly over Afghanistan's territory, reports France 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah, following Pkaistan's bombing of major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday.
items.content: Localised clashes are still continuing along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border while Taliban officials say Pakistani aircraft continue to fly over Afghanistan's territory, reports France 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah, following Pkaistan's bombing of major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday.

items.title: Pakistan declares state of ‘open war’ after bombing major Afghan cities
items.standfirst: Wave of strikes comes after Taliban forces attack Pakistani border troops following earlier action from IslamabadPakistan has bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital, Kabul, with Islamabad’s defence minister declaring that the hostile neighbours were in a state of “open war” as a cycle of retaliatory attacks escalated further.Witnesses in Kabul and Kandahar, the southern Afghan city, reported explosions and jets overhead until dawn, while the Taliban government said later that Pakistani surveillance aircraft were still flying over Afghanistan. Continue reading...
items.content: Wave of strikes comes after Taliban forces attack Pakistani border troops following earlier action from IslamabadPakistan has bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital, Kabul, with Islamabad’s defence minister declaring that the hostile neighbours were in a state of “open war” as a cycle of retaliatory attacks escalated further.Witnesses in Kabul and Kandahar, the southern Afghan city, reported explosions and jets overhead until dawn, while the Taliban government said later that Pakistani surveillance aircraft were still flying over Afghanistan. Continue reading...

items.title: Pakistan’s ‘open war’ on Afghanistan follows years of tensions
items.standfirst: The Pakistani government declared “open war” on the Taliban authorities on Friday after an Afghan offensive launched on Thursday on its border led Islamabad to bomb Kabul in retaliation. But these tensions between the two neighboring countries are not new; they have been going on for years and have been exacerbated since the Taliban returned to power in Kabul in 2021.
items.content: The Pakistani government declared “open war” on the Taliban authorities on Friday after an Afghan offensive launched on Thursday on its border led Islamabad to bomb Kabul in retaliation. But these tensions between the two neighboring countries are not new; they have been going on for years and have been exacerbated since the Taliban returned to power in Kabul in 2021.

items.title: What's behind Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict?
items.standfirst: Pakistan bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday, with Islamabad's defence minister declaring the neighbours at "open war". It comes after months of tit-for-tat clashes, with Islamabad accusing Afghanistan of failing to act against militant groups that carry out attacks in Pakistan, which the Taliban government denies. France 24’s Douglas Herbert takes a closer look at the causes of the conflict.
items.content: Pakistan bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday, with Islamabad's defence minister declaring the neighbours at "open war". It comes after months of tit-for-tat clashes, with Islamabad accusing Afghanistan of failing to act against militant groups that carry out attacks in Pakistan, which the Taliban government denies. France 24’s Douglas Herbert takes a closer look at the causes of the conflict.

items.title: What we know about clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Clashes along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border have escalated to strikes on Kabul and other cities.
items.content: Clashes along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border have escalated to strikes on Kabul and other cities.

items.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan 'open war': How and why we got here?
items.standfirst: Pakistan was once viewed as the sponsor and chief backer of Afghanistan’s Taliban movement. But when Islamabad declared “open war” on Kabul Friday, it marked a dramatic escalation of tensions between the two countries and underscored the regional security implications in a volatile zone.
items.content: Pakistan was once viewed as the sponsor and chief backer of Afghanistan’s Taliban movement. But when Islamabad declared “open war” on Kabul Friday, it marked a dramatic escalation of tensions between the two countries and underscored the regional security implications in a volatile zone.

items.title: Pakistan bombs Kabul after intensifying border clashes with Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours makes a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shakyPakistan bombed Afghanistan’s capital of Kabul and two other provinces on Friday, hours after a cross-border attack, the latest escalation of deadly violence between the volatile neighbours who signed a Qatar-mediated ceasefire in 2025.Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly airstrikes. items.standfirst: Former president tells House oversight committee he is cooperating in the Epstein investigation out of love of country and desire for victims to healSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxJames Comer, the chair of the House oversight committee, said the committee’s list of questions for Bill Clinton grew longer after Hillary Clinton’s deposition yesterday, where she deferred a host of questions to her husband.“So we already had a big portfolio of questions for him, and that increased yesterday,” Comer said at a press conference outside the building where the closed-door deposition was set to begin shortly. items.title: Bill Clinton says he had ‘no idea’ about Epstein’s crimes in House testimony
items.standfirst: Deposition comes one day after Hillary Clinton testified and called proceedings ‘partisan political theater’Sign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxBill Clinton told a congressional committee on Friday that he “had no idea of the crimes” Jeffrey Epstein was committing and insisted he “did nothing wrong” in his relationship with the disgraced financier and convicted sex trafficker.The former president’s remarks came in his opening statement in a deposition to the House of Representatives’ oversight committee, a day after his wife, Hillary Clinton, appeared before the same body and called the proceedings “partisan political theater” and “an insult to the American people”. Continue reading...

items.title: Bill Clinton faces grilling from lawmakers over his connections to Jeffrey Epstein
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, answering for his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago. The closed-door deposition in Chappaqua, comes a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. France 24's Jessica Le Masurier has the latest from Chappaqua.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, answering for his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago. The closed-door deposition in Chappaqua, comes a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. France 24's Jessica Le Masurier has the latest from Chappaqua.

items.title: Epstein files: Clinton hearings 'political theatre to distract public from Trump'
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. However, according to Ian Reifowitz, history professor at SUNY-Empire State University, the hearings a mainly “political theatre” designed to distract the American public from Epstein’s links with Donald Trump.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. However, according to Ian Reifowitz, history professor at SUNY-Empire State University, the hearings a mainly “political theatre” designed to distract the American public from Epstein’s links with Donald Trump.

clusters.title: Marco Rubio orders US officials to stop commentary that could strain Iran talks
clusters.neutral_headline: Marco Rubio orders US officials to stop commentary that could strain Iran talks

items.title: Marco Rubio orders US officials to stop commentary that could strain Iran talks
items.standfirst: Exclusive: memo came after Mike Huckabee’s remarks about Israel sparked alarm inside White HouseSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxThe US secretary of state Marco Rubio told ambassadors in the Middle East to stop making public comments that could inflame tensions and undermine Donald Trump’s pressure on Iran to relinquish its capacity to produce a nuclear weapon, according to a memo obtained by the Guardian.“Giving rising tensions in the region, Chiefs of Mission and embassies at addressee posts must refrain from public statements, interviews, or social media activity that could in any way inflame regional audiences, prejudice sensitive political issues, or complicate US relationships,” the cable said. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: memo came after Mike Huckabee’s remarks about Israel sparked alarm inside White HouseSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxThe US secretary of state Marco Rubio told ambassadors in the Middle East to stop making public comments that could inflame tensions and undermine Donald Trump’s pressure on Iran to relinquish its capacity to produce a nuclear weapon, according to a memo obtained by the Guardian.“Giving rising tensions in the region, Chiefs of Mission and embassies at addressee posts must refrain from public statements, interviews, or social media activity that could in any way inflame regional audiences, prejudice sensitive political issues, or complicate US relationships,” the cable said. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says he is ‘not happy’ with Iran situation and military force is still an option
items.standfirst: US president accuses Tehran of failing to ‘negotiate in good faith’ over its nuclear programmeSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxDonald Trump says he has not made a final decision on whether to launch strikes on Iran but is “not happy” with the situation and military force – including regime change – remains an option.The remarks came at the White House on Friday after talks between the US and Iran on Tehran’s nuclear programme ended inconclusively, with a suggestion that further discussions would be held next week. Continue reading...
items.content: US president accuses Tehran of failing to ‘negotiate in good faith’ over its nuclear programmeSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxDonald Trump says he has not made a final decision on whether to launch strikes on Iran but is “not happy” with the situation and military force – including regime change – remains an option.The remarks came at the White House on Friday after talks between the US and Iran on Tehran’s nuclear programme ended inconclusively, with a suggestion that further discussions would be held next week. items.title: Trump says 'not happy' with Iran talks, but undecided on possible military action
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".
items.content: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".

items.title: US-Iran nuclear talks end without a deal as threat of war grows
items.standfirst: Mediators say more talks to be held next week but no clear evidence two sides any closer on uranium enrichmentHigh-stakes talks between the US and Iran over the future of Tehran’s nuclear programme ended on Thursday without a deal, as the White House weighs a military operation that would mark its largest intervention in the Middle East in decades.The Iranian foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, claimed “good progress” had been made at the talks and Omani mediators predicted negotiations would reconvene at a technical level next week in Vienna. Continue reading...
items.content: Mediators say more talks to be held next week but no clear evidence two sides any closer on uranium enrichmentHigh-stakes talks between the US and Iran over the future of Tehran’s nuclear programme ended on Thursday without a deal, as the White House weighs a military operation that would mark its largest intervention in the Middle East in decades.The Iranian foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, claimed “good progress” had been made at the talks and Omani mediators predicted negotiations would reconvene at a technical level next week in Vienna. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel's Supreme Court allows aid groups facing govt ban to keep working in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel’s top court on Friday froze a government ban on 37 foreign aid organisations operating in Gaza and the occupied West Bank, issuing an interim order that allows the groups to continue their work while the court considers a final ruling.
items.content: Israel’s top court on Friday froze a government ban on 37 foreign aid organisations operating in Gaza and the occupied West Bank, issuing an interim order that allows the groups to continue their work while the court considers a final ruling.

clusters.title: Pentagon official defends standoff with Anthropic, military's AI use
clusters.neutral_headline: Pentagon official defends standoff with Anthropic, military's AI use
bullet_summary: Reported by CBS News, Bloomberg Technology

items.title: Pentagon official defends standoff with Anthropic, military's AI use
items.standfirst: Emil Michael, the U.S. under secretary of defense for research and engineering, speaks with CBS News' Jennifer Jacobs about how the military can benefit from artificial intelligence and defends the Pentagon's stance in its dispute with Anthropic over the use of the AI model Claude. Michael says the military has "made some very good concessions" and hopes Anthropic will do "the right thing" and reach a deal.
items.content: Emil Michael, the U.S. under secretary of defense for research and engineering, speaks with CBS News' Jennifer Jacobs about how the military can benefit from artificial intelligence and defends the Pentagon's stance in its dispute with Anthropic over the use of the AI model Claude. Michael says the military has "made some very good concessions" and hopes Anthropic will do "the right thing" and reach a deal.

items.title: Anthropic Sees Support From Other Tech Workers in Feud With Pentagon
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC got a vote of support from Silicon Valley workers for its increasingly contentious public-relations battle with the Pentagon over how the military can use artificial intelligence.
items.content: Anthropic PBC got a vote of support from Silicon Valley workers for its increasingly contentious public-relations battle with the Pentagon over how the military can use artificial intelligence.

items.title: Pentagon’s Michael on Anthropic Talks, Military Use of AI
items.standfirst: US Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering Emil Michael discusses talks with Anthropic about loosening restrictions on the use of its artificial intelligence technology by the US military. Michael says the Pentagon offered concessions to the company and is open to continuing talks ahead of the Friday afternoon deadline. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: US Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering Emil Michael discusses talks with Anthropic about loosening restrictions on the use of its artificial intelligence technology by the US military. Michael says the Pentagon offered concessions to the company and is open to continuing talks ahead of the Friday afternoon deadline. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Pentagon Open to Continue Anthropic AI Talks Before Deadline

items.content: US Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering Emil Michael says the Pentagon is open to more talks with Anthropic PBC ahead of a 5 pm ET deadline to loosen restrictions on the use of its artificial intelligence technology by the US military. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: What’s driving the Pentagon–Anthropic AI standoff? #politics
items.standfirst: The dispute in plain terms A showdown between the Department of Defense and the A.I. firm Anthropic centers on how military users should be allowed to use powerful generative models. Pentagon officials have pressed Anthropic for broad, unfettered access to its tools for a range of defense…
items.content: The dispute in plain terms A showdown between the Department of Defense and the A.I. firm Anthropic centers on how military users should be allowed to use powerful generative models. Pentagon officials have pressed Anthropic for broad, unfettered access to its tools for a range of defense…

items.title: Anthropic refuses to bend to Pentagon on AI safeguards
items.standfirst: A public showdown between the Trump administration and Anthropic is hitting an impasse as military officials demand the artificial intelligence company bend its ethical policies by Friday or risk damaging its business. Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei drew a sharp red line 24 hours before the deadline, declaring his company “cannot in good conscience accede” to the Pentagon’s final demand to allow unrestricted use of its technology.
items.content: A public showdown between the Trump administration and Anthropic is hitting an impasse as military officials demand the artificial intelligence company bend its ethical policies by Friday or risk damaging its business. Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei drew a sharp red line 24 hours before the deadline, declaring his company “cannot in good conscience accede” to the Pentagon’s final demand to allow unrestricted use of its technology.

items.title: Six planets due to parade across night sky in rare celestial spectacle
items.standfirst: Jupiter, Saturn, Venus, Mercury, Neptune and Uranus will all be visible at same time in curved line across skySix planets will parade across the sky this weekend in a rare celestial spectacle, experts have said.For the next few days, Jupiter, Saturn, Venus, Mercury, Neptune and Uranus will all be visible at the same time in the night sky – although binoculars or a telescope will be needed to spot the latter two planets.
